name: Acute Cholecystitis
clerking:
Golden Questions (5)
  • "Does the pain radiate to your right shoulder or back?" (Boas Sign - Phrenic nerve irritation)
  • "Did this start after a fatty meal?" (CCK release triggers contraction)
  • "How long has the pain lasted? Is it more than 6 hours?" (Distinguishes from Biliary Colic)
  • "Have you had fevers or shivers?" (Suggests inflammation/infection)
  • "Has your urine become dark or stools pale?" (Suggests Complicated/CBD stone)
Differential Diagnosis (5)
  • Biliary Colic: Pain <6h, No fever, Normal WBC.
  • Peptic Ulcer Disease: Burning epigastric pain, association with hunger/food.
  • Right Lower Lobe Pneumonia: Respiratory symptoms, fever, decreased breath sounds.
  • Acute Pancreatitis: Radiates to back, amylase high.
  • Fitz-Hugh-Curtis Syndrome: Perihepatitis associated with PID.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

The primary symptom typically begins as diffuse or periumbilical abdominal pain that eventually localizes to the Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ). The pain is constant and severe, lasting >6 hours. It may radiate to the right scapula (Boas' sign) or shoulder tip (referred pain via phrenic nerve C3,4,5).
Aggravating Factors: Pain may worsen when taking a deep breath, walking, squatting, or riding in a car (peritoneal irritation).
Associated Symptoms: Anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, chills/rigors.
physiology:
Pathophysiology & Etiology

Calculous Cholecystitis (95%): Obstruction of the cystic duct by a gallstone leads to gallbladder distension. This causes venous congestion, lymphatic stasis, and ischemia of the gallbladder wall. The bile becomes concentrated and acts as a chemical irritant (Lysolecithin), causing inflammation. Secondary bacterial superinfection occurs in ~50% of cases.
Acalculous Cholecystitis (5%): Occurs in critically ill patients (burns, sepsis, trauma, TPN) due to bile stasis and ischemia. High mortality.
Organisms: E. coli (Most common), Klebsiella, Enterococcus, Bacteroides.
Risk Factors (5 F's): Fat, Female, Forty, Fertile, Fair. Hemolytic anemia (Pigment stones). Rapid weight loss.
exam:
General Inspection

Tachycardia, Low grade fever (Pyrexia). Patient lies still to avoid pain (peritonism).

Abdominal Examination

Tenderness and guarding in RUQ. Mass may be palpable (Omentum wrapping inflamed GB).
Murphy's Sign: Inspiratory arrest on deep palpation of RUQ (test is positive only if patient stops breathing due to pain, and test is negative on left side).
Boas' Sign: Hyperaesthesia below the right scapula (T9-T11 dermatomes).
Red Flags: Generalized peritonitis (Perforation), Jaundice (Mirizzi/CBD stone), High fever/Rigors (Cholangitis).
inv:
Bedside

Urine Dipstick: Exclude renal colic/UTI/DKA. ECG: Rule out inferior MI.

Laboratory

FBC: Leukocytosis (WBC >10, neutrophilia). CRP: Elevated (Inflammatory marker). LFTs: Usually normal or mild non-specific derangement (ALP/GGT). Significant Bilirubin rise suggests Choledocholithiasis. Amylase/Lipase: To exclude Gallstone Pancreatitis.

Imaging

USG Abdomen (Gold Standard):
- Thickened GB wall >3mm.
- Pericholecystic fluid.
- Presence of gallstones/sludge.
- Positive sonographic Murphy's sign.
- Distended gallbladder (>4cm width).
HIDA Scan: Functional scan. Used if USG equivocal. Non-visualization of GB suggests cystic duct obstruction.
CT Abdomen: Not first line, but can show complications like emphysematous cholecystitis or gangrene.
mgmt:
Resuscitation

NBM (Nil By Mouth) for bowel rest. IV Fluids (Crystaloids e.g., Hartmann's) to correct dehydration. Analgesia (NSAIDs like Diclofenac PR/IM are superior for biliary pain; Opioids like Morphine if severe). Antiemetics.

Medical

IV Antibiotics (Broad spectrum e.g. Cefuroxime + Metronidazole covering Gram-negatives like E. coli/Klebsiella and Anaerobes).

Surgical (Definitive)

Early Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy: Recommended within 72 hours of onset (or within 1 week). Reduces hospital stay compared to interval surgery.

Interventional

Percutaneous Cholecystostomy: USG-guided drainage of the gallbladder. Reserved for high-risk surgical candidates (Tokyo Grade III, ICU patients, severe comorbidities) to "cool down" the inflammation before potential later surgery.
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Empyema of Gallbladder: Pus filled GB (Sepsis/High fever).
  • Gangrenous Cholecystitis: Ischemia/Perforation.
  • Biliary Peritonitis: Rupture.
  • Cholecystoenteric Fistula: Leads to Gallstone Ileus (Rigler's Triad).
Treatment Related
  • Bile Duct Injury (BDI): Major complication (0.3%).
  • Bile Leak: From cystic duct stump or Liver bed (Luschka).
  • Retained Stone: CBD stone missed.
  • Post-cholecystectomy Syndrome: Persistent pain.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Tokyo Guidelines 2018 (Severity Grading)
  • Grade I (Mild): Healthy patient, no organ dysfunction. -> Early Lap Chole.
  • Grade II (Moderate): WBC >18, palpable tender mass, duration >72h, local inflammation. -> Antibiotics/Drainage then Surgery.
  • Grade III (Severe): Organ Dysfunction (Hypotension, confusion, respiratory failure). -> Urgent Drainage (Cholecystostomy) + ICU.
ðŸ’Ž Mirizzi Syndrome
A rare complication where a large gallstone impacted in the Cystic duct or Hartmann's pouch causes extrinsic compression of the Common Hepatic Duct, leading to obstructive jaundice.

name: Gallstones (Biliary Colic)
clerking:
Golden Questions (5)
  • "Does the pain come and go?"
  • "Does it go away completely between attacks?"
  • "Is your urine dark or eyes yellow?" (Rule out CBD stone)
  • "Did this happen after eating greasy food?"
  • "Any fever or shivers?" (Rule out Cholecystitis)
Differential Diagnosis (5)
  • Acute Cholecystitis: Fever, pain >6h.
  • Gastritis/GERD: Burning pain.
  • Pancreatitis: Back radiation, severe.
  • Peptic Ulcer: Hunger pain.
  • Renal Colic: Loin to groin.
history:
History of Presenting Illness

Colicky RUQ/Epigastric pain, post-prandial (fatty food). Lasts <6 hours. No fever. Nausea/Vomiting common. Pain resolves completely.
physiology:
Pathophysiology & Etiology

Mechanism: Supersaturation of bile with cholesterol -> Nucleation of crystals -> Growth into stones. Contraction of GB against obstructed cystic duct causes colic.
Stone Types:
- Cholesterol (Mixed): 80% of stones. Radiolucent.
- Pigment (Black): Hemolysis, Cirrhosis. Radiopaque.
- Pigment (Brown): Infection/Stasis (Asian population).
Risks: 5 Fs, Hemolysis, Crohn's (bile salt malabsorption), TPN.
exam:
Signs

Abdomen soft/non-tender between attacks. Negative Murphy's. Afebrile. No jaundice.
inv:
Labs

Normal WBC, CRP, LFTs (Crucial negative findings).

Imaging

USG Abdomen: Stones with acoustic shadowing. Thin GB wall (<3mm). No fluid.
mgmt:
Conservative

Analgesia (Diclofenac > Opioids), Low fat diet.

Surgical

Elective Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy to prevent complications.
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Acute Cholecystitis.
  • Choledocholithiasis (Jaundice/Cholangitis).
  • Gallstone Pancreatitis.
  • Gallstone Ileus.
  • Mucocele of GB.
Treatment Related
  • Bile Duct Injury.
  • Bleeding.
  • Infection.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Saint's Triad
Gallstones + Diverticulosis + Hiatus Hernia.
ðŸ’Ž Mercedes Benz Sign
Gas within a gallstone (fissures) seen on CT/X-ray. Indicates nitrogen gas accumulation.

name: Acute Pancreatitis
clerking:
Golden Questions (5)
  • "Does the pain go straight through to your back?"
  • "Does sitting forward help?"
  • "Do you drink alcohol? How much?"
  • "History of gallstones?"
  • "Any recent ERCP or trauma?"
Differential Diagnosis (5)
  • Perforated PUD: Air under diaphragm.
  • Acute Cholecystitis: RUQ pain, Murphy's +.
  • MI: ECG changes.
  • Ruptured AAA: Shock, Pulsatile mass.
  • Mesenteric Ischemia: Pain out of proportion.
history:
HOPI

Sudden severe epigastric pain radiating to back (transfixion). "Boring" pain. Vomiting does not relieve pain.
Causes (GET SMASHED): Gallstones (50%), Alcohol (30%), Trauma, Steroids, Mumps, Autoimmune, Scorpion, Hypercalcemia, ERCP, Drugs.
physiology:
Pathophysiology

Premature activation of trypsinogen to trypsin within pancreas -> Autodigestion -> Inflammation -> SIRS.
Phases:
1. Early (1st week): SIRS/Organ failure.
2. Late (>1 week): Local complications (Necrosis/Infection).
exam:
Signs

Epigastric tenderness. Dehydration.
Red Flags: Cullen's (umbilicus) or Grey Turner's (flank) bruising = Hemorrhagic Necrosis.
inv:
Labs

Amylase/Lipase: >3x Upper Limit Normal. ABG (Lactate/Hypoxia). Calcium.

Imaging

USG (stones). CT Pancreas: After 48h for necrosis.
mgmt:
Supportive

Aggressive IV Fluids (Hartmann's), Analgesia (Opioids). Early enteral nutrition (NG/NJ).

Specific

ERCP (if cholangitis). Cholecystectomy (same admission).
complications:
Disease Progression
  • Early: Shock, ARDS, Renal Failure (MODS), Hypocalcemia, DIC.
  • Late (>4 weeks): Pseudocyst, Walled-off Necrosis (WON), Abscess.
  • Chronic: Diabetes, Malabsorption (Steatorrhea).
Treatment Related
  • ERCP Pancreatitis.
  • Bleeding from necrosis debridement.
  • Fistula.

PANCREAS mnemonic. Score â‰¥3 = Severe.
